thread.title: Kalgoorlie driver charged with running down teen fights for hometown hearing
thread.title_full: Kalgoorlie driver charged with running down teen fights for hometown hearing

author: Joanna Menagh
title: Kalgoorlie driver charged with running down teen fights for hometown hearing
text:
Map: Kalgoorlie 6430 
A man accused of running down a teenager whose death sparked a riot by member of the Aboriginal community in the Western Australian town of Kalgoorlie, has opposed a bid to hold the trial in Perth rather than his hometown. 
The 55-year-old man, whose name has been suppressed by the court, is facing a charge of unlawfully killing the 14-year-old in August last year. 
His body was found in bushland after police responded to reports of a crash between a motorcycle and a utility. 
During the accused's first court appearance members of the Aboriginal community staged a protest outside the courthouse, calling for an upgrade of the charge to murder. 
The protest turned violent, as people hurled rocks and massed in the town's centre, with a dozen police injured, five police cars damaged and the courthouse placed into lockdown. 
Community elders have since raised concerns about vitriolic social media posts alleging Aboriginal youths were responsible for vehicle thefts and community crime. 
Family members of the slain teen have asked the ABC not to use his name or image, for cultural reasons. 
Today in the Supreme Court in Perth, the accused pleaded not guilty to the manslaughter charge and a five-day trial was scheduled to begin on July 17. 
The court heard prosecutors would be applying for the trial to be held in Perth instead of Kalgoorlie but the application was opposed by the man. 
His lawyer, Seamus Rafferty, also said he wanted it noted his client had offered to plead guilty to the lesser charge of dangerous driving occasioning death. 
The man, who appeared via video link from an undisclosed prison, was remanded in custody until he faces court again next month.
